awd_titl_txt: On the origin of plasmons in metal nanoparticles
awd_abstract_narration:
Nontechnical description: Using atoms as elemental building blocks to construct nanoscale functional materials is of major importance in materials research. This project focuses on the development of new methodologies for precise assembly of metal atoms into functional nanoparticles, and the investigation of how the properties of these materials depend on nanoparticle size. This project offers new opportunities for exploring the novel properties of atomically precise metal nanoparticle materials, bringing broad impact across several important areas. Leveraging our capability of manipulating the bonding between atoms to achieve new functionalities, this project is set to impact fields such as catalysis, energy conversion, chemical sensing and biomedicine. This research effort additionally enables impact on regional outreach and educational activities. Graduate and undergraduate students participating in this project receive interdisciplinary training, which contributes to their future careers in the increasingly competitive and fast-moving area of materials research. 

Technical description:	 Metal nanoparticles (e.g. Au, Ag) are being intensely pursued owing to their unique plasmon properties. Ultrasmall metal nanoparticles (<3 nm) no longer exhibit metallic properties, with the plasmon disappearing due to quantum size effect. However, the fundamental origin of plasmons has not been elucidated due to the difficulties in controlling the atomic monodipsersity and structural uniformity of ultrasmall nanoparticles. This project tackles the challenges of creating atomically precise nanoparticles, and conducts a systematic investigation of the evolutionary behavior from the quantized state to the metallic/plasmonic state. The proposed research expands the current understanding of metal nanomaterials. Probing the transition behavior in gold nanoparticles is used to establish a model approach for future studies of other metal nanoparticle systems (e.g., Ag, Cu, bimetals.) The educational component of the project broadens student participation by engaging high school students and teachers, some of whom are from underrepresented minority groups. The educational efforts help attract students into science and technology by cultivating their research interests and through participation in materials research.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The major goal of this project is to investigate the size evolution from the nonmetallic to metallic (or plasmonic) state of gold nanoparticles with atomic precision. The specific aims of this project includes: i) atomically precise control of Au nanoparticles in the size range from Au144 to Au333 protected by thiol, over which the plasmon emergences; ii) studies on the optical property evolution from Au144 to Au333 by optical spectroscopy; and iii) probing the electron and phonon dynamics to monitor the nonmetallic to metallic state transition.

Broader impacts include the extension to Ag, Cu and bimetal systems, as well as catalysis. The project also provides opportunities for student training and benefits their future careers in STEM areas.

 

Major Activities: In yr 5, we investigated the effect of Ag doping on the nonmetal to metal transition using atomically precise Au144(SR)60 as a model, where SR = thiolate ligand. We first measured by electrochemistry the energy gap of Au144-xAgx(SR)60 with controlled x doping levels. We then investigated the ultrafast electron dynamics and phonons that are coupled with the electronic motions by femtosecond spectroscopy. With respect to the electron-phonon coupling interactions, we chose Au25(SR)18 and Au38(SR)26 as examples and performed cryogenic photoluminescence and absorption spectroscopies to extract the coupling strength and effects on the electronic properties. We have also succeeded in atomically precise, quantum-sized gold nanorods such as Au42(SR)42 and determined its total structure (metal core plus surface ligand configurations) by X-ray crystallography.

Significant results:

Our femtosecond and electrochemical probing results on Au144-xAgx demonstrated that Au144-xAgx with various levels of doping retain the nonmetallic state, with energy gaps ranging from 0.15-0.2 eV (see pub. 1). Cryogenic spectroscopy revealed two types of phonons that are coupled with the electronic motions in spherical Au25(SR)18 and Au38(SR)26 (see pub. 2 and 3).

For the rod-shaped Au42(SR)32, we discovered a strong photothermal effect in the near-infrared (NIR) light regime, which makes this material quite promising for photothermal therapy application (see pub. 4). In addition, we found that Au42(SR)32 emits in the NIR with high quantum yield 11% (see pub. 5), nearly an order of magnitude than commercial NIR dyes.

Toward the catalytic application, we explored two series of Au NPs: (1) Au38(SR)24, Au144(SR)60 and Au333(SR)79 (where SR=2-phenylethanethiolate); (2) Au28(SR’)20, Au36(SR’)24 and Au279(SR’)84 (where SR’=4-tert-butylbenzenethiolate). Our results reveal the unprecedented atomic-level size effect in electrocatalytic CO2 conversion, as well as the catalytic active-site structures (see pub. 6).

Pub 1.

Single-electron charging and ultrafast dynamics of bimetallic Au144-xAgx(PET)(60) nanoclusters

X Du, H Ma, X Zhang, M Zhou, Z Liu, H Wang, G Wang, R Jin

Nano research 2022, 15 (9), 8573-8578.

 

Pub 2.

Tailoring the Electron–Phonon Interaction in Au25(SR)18 Nanoclusters via Ligand Engineering and Insight into Luminescence

Z Liu, Y Li, E Kahng, S Xue, X Du, S Li, R Jin

ACS nano 2022, 16 (11), 18448-18458.

 

Pub 3.

Photoluminescence of the Au38(SR)26 nanocluster comprises three radiative processes

L Luo, Z Liu, X Du, R Jin

Communications Chemistry 2023, 6 (1), 22.

 

Pub 4.

Atomically Precise Au42 Nanorods with Longitudinal Excitons for an Intense Photothermal Effect

Y Li, Y Song, X Zhang, T Liu, T Xu, H Wang, D Jiang, R Jin

Journal of the American Chemical Society 2022, 144 (27), 12381-12389.

 

Pub 5.

Near-Infrared Dual Emission from the Au42(SR)32 Nanocluster and Tailoring of Intersystem Crossing

L Luo, Z Liu, X Du, R Jin

Journal of the American Chemical Society 2022, 144 (42), 19243-19247

 

Pub 6.

Dissecting Critical Factors for Electrochemical CO2 Reduction on Atomically Precise Au Nanoclusters

S Li, AV Nagarajan, X Du, Y Li, Z Liu, DR Kauffman, G Mpourmpakis, R Jin.

Angewandte Chemie 2022, 134 (47), e202211771.

 

Student training and professional development:

In addition to graduate students training, two undergraduate students (E Kahng and I. Coburn) also actively participated in the research and E. Kahng coauthored in one publication (see pub 2). The training will benefit their future careers in academia and industry.

Jin was invited to give a talk at the ACS national meeting (April, 2023).
